data analysis.description:
Data analysis is the process of extracting information and knowledge from raw data.
The goal is to make data-driven decisions.

pandas.description: pandas is a Python library used for data analysis. It allows you to work with tables and data in DataFrame format efficiently.
pandas.example:
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
df.head()

numpy.description: numpy is a library for numerical operations and arrays. It is a core part of digital data processing in Python.
numpy.example:
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])
print(np.mean(arr))

matplotlib.description: matplotlib is a library used to create data visualizations. It helps you draw charts such as bars, lines, and points.

seaborn.description: seaborn is built on top of matplotlib. It is used to create beautiful and advanced statistical plots easily.
seaborn.example:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
df = sns.load_dataset('iris')
sns.pairplot(df)

read.description: Read functions in pandas are used to load data from various sources. After loading, the data is stored in a structure called DataFrame for analysis.
read.example:
import pandas as pd

# CSV
df1 = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Excel
df2 = pd.read_excel('data.xlsx')

# JSON
df3 = pd.read_json('data.json')

# Google Sheets
sheet_url = 'https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1abc123xyz/export?format=csv'
df4 = pd.read_csv(sheet_url)

# From URL
url = 'https://example.com/data.csv'
df5 = pd.read_csv(url)

head.description:
Displays the first 5 rows of the dataset by default.
Useful for inspecting the beginning of your data.

tail.description:
Displays the last 5 rows of the dataset.
Useful for reviewing the end of the data.

describe.description:
Displays a statistical summary of numeric columns.
Includes mean, standard deviation, max, and min values.

info.description: Shows general information about the DataFrame. Includes column names, data types, and non-null counts.

value_counts.description:
Counts the occurrences of each unique value in a specific column.
Useful for analyzing categorical data distribution.
